title: INVENTORY / LEDGER OF FAILURE
description:
Perform a closer inspection of the ledger found in the trash (your official paperwork). Find:
1. serial number
2. forms
3. notes on cases
4. wife's letter
5. toilet smell

dialogueTree.title: Damaged Ledger: "It's the ledger you found in the tr..."
dialogueTree.text: It's the ledger you found in the trash: a cabbage of papers hanging from the board, barely held together by the clip -- and made complete by the faint smell of urinal cleaner.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Oh, and a *cool* piece of toilet pa..."
links.text: Oh, and a *cool* piece of toilet paper is stuck to the back.

links.title: You: "Inspect the toilet paper."
links.text: Inspect the toilet paper.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "It's just toilet paper, sticking to..."
links.text: It's just toilet paper, sticking to the back of the plastic clipboard. You can take it off if you want.

links.title: You: "(Take it off.)"
links.text: (Take it off.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Still wet, the toilet paper -- I me..."
links.text: Still wet, the toilet paper -- I mean *kitchen tissue*, sorry -- peels off the plastic easily. All you have to do is shake it off your finger, and voil√†, the ledger now looks (marginally) better.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Still wet, the toilet paper peels o..."
links.text: Still wet, the toilet paper peels off the plastic easily. All you have to do is shake it off your finger and voila! The ledger now looks (marginally) better.

links.title: You: "(Leave it there, it's cool.)"
links.text: (Leave it there, it's cool.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Mhm, cool toilet paper... I mean ki..."
links.text: Mhm, cool toilet paper... I mean kitchen tissue.

links.title: Conceptualization: "It says: everyone look at me and my..."
links.text: It says: everyone look at me and my *kitchen tissue* covered cop ledger! I don't *care*. My ledger is droopy and  smells like a urinal. Not a new addition, though. So keep that *styling case* open, my friend...

links.title: Half Light: "This stinking tissue will show ever..."
links.text: This stinking tissue will show everyone what a bum you are. How little you give a shit. This toilet paper will PUNISH the world.

links.title: Half Light: "This toilet paper will show everyon..."
links.text: This toilet paper will show everyone what a bum you are. How little you give a shit. This toilet paper will PUNISH the world.

links.title: Conceptualization: "It says: everyone look at me and my..."
links.text: It says: everyone look at me and my toilet paper covered cop ledger! I don't *care*. My ledger is droopy and it smells like a urinal. Not a new addition, though. So keep that *styling case* open, my friend...

links.title: Conceptualization: "It says: everyone look at me and my..."
links.text: It says: everyone look at me and my *kitchen tissue* covered cop ledger! I don't *care*. My ledger is droopy and it smells like a urinal.

links.title: Conceptualization: "It says: everyone look at me and my..."
links.text: It says: everyone look at me and my toilet paper covered cop ledger! I don't *care*. My ledger is droopy and it smells like a urinal.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "*Way* cool."
links.text: *Way* cool.

links.title: You: "Maybe it's kitchen tissue? They loo..."
links.text: Maybe it's kitchen tissue? They look exactly the same.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "If you *want* it to be kitchen tiss..."
links.text: If you *want* it to be kitchen tissue, it can be kitchen tissue.

links.title: Perception (Smell): "It's not though. It's toilet paper."
links.text: It's not though. It's toilet paper.

links.title: You: "Inspect the clip."
links.text: Inspect the clip.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "An aluminium block runs the width o..."
links.text: An aluminium block runs the width of the board, biting down on the paperwork. Its crocodile teeth are the only thing keeping the papers together. On it, the perforated watermark counting the achievements of the person you used to be.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "A bunch of sodden papers sag from t..."
links.text: A bunch of sodden papers sag from the clipboard in your hand. It's a sorry sight.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "An aluminium block runs the width o..."
links.text: An aluminium block runs the width of the board, biting down on the paperwork. Its crocodile teeth are the only thing keeping the papers together. A regular pencil, the tip worn down to nothing, has been attached to the clip.

links.title: You: "Run your finger across the aluminiu..."
links.text: Run your finger across the aluminium.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The surface is interrupted by a sil..."
links.text: The surface is interrupted by a silvery *sticker*. It's rectangular, sparkling with iridescence. You don't know how you didn't notice it before...

links.title: Perception (Sight): "Looks like an official mark, made t..."
links.text: Looks like an official mark, made to be low visibility outside the right circumstances.

links.title: Logic: "It is similar to the RCM watermark..."
links.text: It is similar to the RCM watermark on your blazer the lieutenant mentioned. Didn't he say something about the headlights of his motor carriage? That you can read these there?

links.title: You: ""Hey lieutenant. What is this?" (Po..."
links.text: "Hey lieutenant. What is this?" (Point to the sticker.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""What?" He is lost in his own notes..."
links.text: "What?" He is lost in his own notes. It takes a moment for him to see it. "That thing? It's a halogen watermark. We use it for adding information to RCM property."

links.title: You: ""Interesting. What kind of informat..."
links.text: "Interesting. What kind of information?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""It depends. Aside from an anti-cou..."
links.text: "It depends. Aside from an anti-counterfeiting stamp, mine has my station number and address. The information varies by date of issue."

links.title: Logic: "Maybe yours will have how many case..."
links.text: Maybe yours will have how many cases you've solved?

links.title: Esprit de Corps: "How many years you've been on the f..."
links.text: How many years you've been on the force, he's thinking. It'll have that.

links.title: Half Light: "Your kill count. Yours will surely..."
links.text: Your kill count. Yours will surely have your kill count.

links.title: You: ""How can I read it?""
links.text: "How can I read it?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Any capable light with the right w..."
links.text: "Any capable light with the right wavelength will do."

links.title: You: ""Before, you mentioned the headligh..."
links.text: "Before, you mentioned the headlights of your vehicle?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Yes." There is a pause. "RCM vehic..."
links.text: "Yes." There is a pause. "RCM vehicles have headlights tuned especially to reveal halogen watermarks."

links.title: Interfacing: "This means you can read the waterma..."
links.text: This means you can read the watermarks, if you just turn the lights on.

links.title: Empathy: "The lieutenant fears this will lead..."
links.text: The lieutenant fears this will lead to fiddling with the delicate, folding headlights on his motor carriage. They're dear to him.

links.title: Empathy: "The lieutenant would rather not hav..."
links.text: The lieutenant would rather not have you rummaging around, looking for the lights in his vehicle...

links.title: You: ""Like -- for example?""
links.text: "Like -- for example?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""All RCM vehicles have headlights d..."
links.text: "All RCM vehicles have headlights designed to reveal halogen watermarks. Mine too."

links.title: You: ""That's all, thank you." (Conclude...."
links.text: "That's all, thank you." (Conclude.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Okay." He returns to his neatly ke..."
links.text: "Okay." He returns to his neatly kept notes...

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "...while a bunch of sodden papers s..."
links.text: ...while a bunch of sodden papers sag from the clipboard in your hand. It's a sorry sight.

links.title: You: ""Lieutenant, is this one of the *ho..."
links.text: "Lieutenant, is this one of the *hologram watermarks* you mentioned?" (Point to the sticker.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""What?" He is lost in his own notes..."
links.text: "What?" He is lost in his own notes. It takes a moment for him to see it. "Yes, a halogen watermark used for adding information to RCM property."

links.title: You: "What can I do?"
links.text: What can I do?

links.title: Logic: "You should turn them on and get in..."
links.text: You should turn them on and get in front of those headlights -- see what happens. There may be information on there, a *halogen watermark* he called it.

links.title: You: "When I get the chance. (Accept.)"
links.text: When I get the chance. (Accept.)

links.title: Logic: "It'd be nifty if you found somethin..."
links.text: It'd be nifty if you found something that way, wouldn't it? The papers still sagging from the clipboard in your hand -- not so nifty.

links.title: You: "Not interested, Logic. I don't take..."
links.text: Not interested, Logic. I don't take orders from anyone. (Decline.)

links.title: Logic: "Obviously, yes. The papers still sa..."
links.text: Obviously, yes. The papers still sag from the clipboard in your hand. It's a defiant sight. You're a hero.

links.title: You: "Forget about it for now -- how is t..."
links.text: Forget about it for now -- how is the rest of this thing doing?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Not good. A bunch of sodden papers..."
links.text: Not good. A bunch of sodden papers sags from the clipboard in your hand.

links.title: You: "What is this?"
links.text: What is this?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "To be honest: you have little to no..."
links.text: To be honest: you have little to no idea. You're dumb. And alone.

links.title: Esprit de Corps: "Somewhere -- not here -- the helpfu..."
links.text: Somewhere -- not here -- the helpful Lieutenant Kitsuragi is making notes in his blue notebook. He tilts it ever so slightly, a glowing rectangle catches the light. He could advise you with this. The next moment...

links.title: You: "Enough of the clip. (Back.)"
links.text: Enough of the clip. (Back.)

links.title: You: "Browse the case files again."
links.text: Browse the case files again.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Arson. Petty theft. Spousal abuse -..."
links.text: Arson. Petty theft. Spousal abuse -- handwritten logs on investigations dating back to January, ¬¥51 -- stamped CASE FILES, COMMIT TO PAPER. These are the last couple of months of your life.

links.title: You: "That's *it*?"
links.text: That's *it*?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The notebook is *annual*, it says '..."
links.text: The notebook is *annual*, it says '51 on what remains of its cover -- a molten strap of cardboard. Everything prior to this must have belonged to a previous volume. In short: there was more.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Judging by the creases on your fore..."
links.text: Judging by the creases on your forehead and the lines on your cheeks -- too much more. Going back years, decades even....

links.title: You: ""Is two cases a week a good case lo..."
links.text: "Is two cases a week a good case load, lieutenant?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Huh?" He raises his nose from his..."
links.text: "Huh?" He raises his nose from his notes. "Two *complex* cases to undertake is a lot, yes. You *really* have to push yourself. I would not suggest it. Lest you start making mistakes."

links.title: You: ""Two cases a week appears to have b..."
links.text: "Two cases a week appears to have been my load, lieutenant. I'm not sure I completed them though."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Two?" He raises both eyebrows. "Th..."
links.text: "Two?" He raises both eyebrows. "That's a lot. I didn't mean to say you're making mistakes, by the way. That was presumptuous of me."

links.title: You: ""I'm sure I made plenty of mistakes.""
links.text: "I'm sure I made plenty of mistakes."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""That's okay." He nods, then turns..."
links.text: "That's okay." He nods, then turns back to his own case files. "We all make mistakes."

links.title: Esprit de Corps: "God knows I've made my share... he..."
links.text: God knows I've made my share... he tries not to think of them.

links.title: You: ""I burned out all right.""
links.text: "I burned out all right."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""That's okay." He nods, then turns..."
links.text: "That's okay." He nods, then turns back to his own case files. "We all do, sooner or later."

links.title: Endurance: "Not you. You are an *eternal machin..."
links.text: Not you. You are an *eternal machine*.

links.title: You: ""A nice brisk pace. The way I like..."
links.text: "A nice brisk pace. The way I like it."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""I prefer a *normal* case load." He..."
links.text: "I prefer a *normal* case load." He turns back to his own case files. "It's a matter of methods."

links.title: You: "Nod and return to the case notes."
links.text: Nod and return to the case notes.

links.title: You: "How much is that -- two new cases a..."
links.text: How much is that -- two new cases a week?

links.title: Logic: "A lot? A little? You have no idea,..."
links.text: A lot? A little? You have no idea, this all depends.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Does it? It feels like a *lot*. Or..."
links.text: Does it? It feels like a *lot*. Or maybe even more than a lot. It feels like *too much*.

links.title: You: "Inspect the handwriting in the file..."
links.text: Inspect the handwriting in the files.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "It's *inornate*. Nearly illegible,..."
links.text: It's *inornate*. Nearly illegible, yet marching in orderly lines.

links.title: Visual Calculus: "*Pedagogical* somehow. Brash. It mu..."
links.text: *Pedagogical* somehow. Brash. It must be yours for you to be able to read it. These are the lines of someone who has written by hand *a lot* and has developed a style only they themselves -- or *you yourself* -- can decipher.

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Written in a rush. In pain. A race..."
links.text: Written in a rush. In pain. A race to beat your own heart's pulse to some dark finish line.

links.title: Interfacing: "Your hand cramps up merely looking..."
links.text: Your hand cramps up merely looking at the scribbles, drawn -- as by some magnet -- to the red chequered margins. Fast, but always *straight*...

links.title: You: "Who is this person?"
links.text: Who is this person?

links.title: Pain Threshold: "Wearing out. Nearly gone. Sometimes..."
links.text: Wearing out. Nearly gone. Sometimes he forgets to keep the pen on the paper as he moves his hand and the lines vanish from underneath...

links.title: You: "Return to the case files."
links.text: Return to the case files.

links.title: You: "There was mention of a... *naming c..."
links.text: There was mention of a... *naming convention* here?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yes. It appears you employ a... sha..."
links.text: Yes. It appears you employ a... shall we say *robust yet literary* system. Each investigation has its case number written on the margins. Yet, still more tellingly, most are accompanied by a *name*.

links.title: Conceptualization: "A *title* one might say even. One t..."
links.text: A *title* one might say even. One that draws inspiration from snoop fiction and Vespertine cop show staples.

links.title: You: "Oh my, and they're written in capit..."
links.text: Oh my, and they're written in capital letters too...

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yes, all caps. One is called THE NE..."
links.text: Yes, all caps. One is called THE NEXT WORLD MURAL, another THE SQUARE BULLET HOLE MURDERS. Another yet: THE UNSOLVABLE CASE.

links.title: You: "More?"
links.text: More?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Others appear more light-hearted: T..."
links.text: Others appear more light-hearted: THE GUYS ON A COUCH IN AN UNEXPECTED LOCATION and THE MURDER AT THE HOOKAH PARLOUR, even the rare article-free COLLAPSING TENEMENT. Murder features prominently throughout.

links.title: Half Light: "You like this grimy *murdering*, do..."
links.text: You like this grimy *murdering*, don't you?

links.title: Electrochemistry: "Wish there was one in there about a..."
links.text: Wish there was one in there about a drug den, you love those. Gets the *blood* pumping.

links.title: Visual Calculus: "No, you don't. You're a human measu..."
links.text: No, you don't. You're a human measuring instrument, almost entirely intellectual.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "It's going to take an effort to pie..."
links.text: It's going to take an effort to piece these case files together, but it can be done -- later, once you're done inspecting them up close.

links.title: You: "I don't wanna... (Back to the case..."
links.text: I don't wanna... (Back to the case files.)

links.title: You: ""Kim, my cases appear to employ som..."
links.text: "Kim, my cases appear to employ some kind of... naming convention."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Yes, how very childish of you," he..."
links.text: "Yes, how very childish of you," he mumbles. "In your -- and my -- defence, almost everyone in the RCM uses the *titular* system. In addition to the official alphanumeric."

links.title: You: ""Why is that?""
links.text: "Why is that?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""It's a holdover from the early day..."
links.text: "It's a holdover from the early days of the RCM -- right after the Revolution, when the organization had little idea how to do things. It persists in an *unofficial* capacity. Officers use these titles to refer to their work among themselves."

links.title: You: ""I seem to have named a case "THE S..."
links.text: "I seem to have named a case "THE SQUARE BULLET HOLE MURDERS."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Again, in your defence, I seem to..."
links.text: "Again, in your defence, I seem to have named one..." He peeks into his notes. "THE MAN WITH THE HOLE IN HIS HEAD. That was a real person, his death was real. Still I named it that. To amuse myself."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "He smiles. "I pray his loved ones n..."
links.text: He smiles. "I pray his loved ones never find out."

links.title: You: ""What happened to him?""
links.text: "What happened to him?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Rail spike through the head. He di..."
links.text: "Rail spike through the head. He died. It was a work place accident."

links.title: You: "Don't mention it."
links.text: Don't mention it.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Your secret is safe with the rotten..."
links.text: Your secret is safe with the rotten cabbage of papers in your hand. Writing covers almost all the pages.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""You mean the alphanumeric -- offic..."
links.text: "You mean the alphanumeric -- officer, precinct, time of arrival at the scene?"

links.title: You: ""That's the one." (Lie.)"
links.text: "That's the one." (Lie.)

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Good. That's a good one...""
links.text: "Good. That's a good one..."

links.title: Drama: "He understands you're *concealing*..."
links.text: He understands you're *concealing* something, sire.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""...but -- do you also use the *tit..."
links.text: "...but -- do you also use the *titular*?"

links.title: You: ""Okay. Yes. It appears I do.""
links.text: "Okay. Yes. It appears I do."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Well... so do I. In our defence, o..."
links.text: "Well... so do I. In our defence, officer, almost everyone in the RCM does."

links.title: You: ""No. I don't know what you're talki..."
links.text: "No. I don't know what you're talking about."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Right. Of course." He returns to h..."
links.text: "Right. Of course." He returns to his notes, leaving you to yours.

links.title: You: ""No, I mean a... *non-numeric* one...."
links.text: "No, I mean a... *non-numeric* one. With titles."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Oh, you mean the *titular*. Yes, w..."
links.text: "Oh, you mean the *titular*. Yes, well... So do I. In our defence -- almost everyone in the RCM does."

links.title: You: ""Kim, I have a name for this case.""
links.text: "Kim, I have a name for this case."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Huh? Oh, yes. The name, good. What..."
links.text: "Huh? Oh, yes. The name, good. What is it?"

links.title: You: ""THE HANGED MAN.""
links.text: "THE HANGED MAN."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Great! That's great. That's actual..."
links.text: "Great! That's great. That's actually what *I* was thinking too -- THE HANGED MAN. Good, strong name. We have a very good name for the case now."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "He flips the pages of his notebook...."
links.text: He flips the pages of his notebook. "I'm going to start calling it THE HANGED MAN. It's good we sorted this out."

links.title: You: ""THE FURIES ARE AT HOME IN THE MIRR..."
links.text: "THE FURIES ARE AT HOME IN THE MIRROR."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Furies. Yes. Well." It's obvious h..."
links.text: "Furies. Yes. Well." It's obvious he doesn't like it. "I don't know. I have to be honest -- I'm not experiencing the *internal strife* that refers to. And also..." He furrows his brow.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Could we make it less *poetic* som..."
links.text: "Could we make it less *poetic* somehow? Just a normal case name, you know? Think -- what would that be? A good *normal* name?"

links.title: Conceptualization: "Yes-yes, you know what that normal..."
links.text: Yes-yes, you know what that normal name is -- but it's so plain... *anything* else, please.

links.title: You: ""THE SETTING SUN.""
links.text: "THE SETTING SUN."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Okay. Okay." He nods. "It's a good..."
links.text: "Okay. Okay." He nods. "It's a good name, but it has *one* problem -- this case has nothing to do with the setting sun. At all. It has nothing to do with that. So..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""...something more concrete perhaps..."
links.text: "...something more concrete perhaps? Do you have something *concrete*? Mundane. *Usual*."

links.title: Inland Empire: "Usual is boring. We don't do that."
links.text: Usual is boring. We don't do that.

links.title: You: ""SHIT ON A STICK.""
links.text: "SHIT ON A STICK."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Ha! Yes." He isn't actually laughi..."
links.text: "Ha! Yes." He isn't actually laughing. "I have to tell you officer, I don't appreciate *ironic* titles. Other officers will have to use this as reference. If it's 'IDIOT', or 'COCK FINGER'..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""They're not going to *get* it. The..."
links.text: "They're not going to *get* it. They're going to think: an idiot and a cock finger were on this case. So -- do you have something less *funny*?"

links.title: Horrific Necktie: "Fun is *outlawed* with this guy. Wh..."
links.text: Fun is *outlawed* with this guy. What a narc.

links.title: You: ""Actually, I don't have one.""
links.text: "Actually, I don't have one."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Oh... Well, then maybe I can sugge..."
links.text: "Oh... Well, then maybe I can suggest one?"

links.title: You: ""No.""
links.text: "No."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Okay then." He returns to his note..."
links.text: "Okay then." He returns to his notes, abruptly. "The case doesn't need to have a name."

links.title: Empathy: "It actually. Does. You've offended..."
links.text: It actually. Does. You've offended him.

links.title: You: ""Go ahead.""
links.text: "Go ahead."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""THE HANGED MAN.""
links.text: "THE HANGED MAN."

links.title: Empathy: "He really likes that name."
links.text: He really likes that name.

links.title: You: ""Solid name.""
links.text: "Solid name."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Thank you," the lieutenant nods. "..."
links.text: "Thank you," the lieutenant nods. "I think so too. Good and *normal*."

links.title: You: ""That's idiotic," (mockingly,) "*th..."
links.text: "That's idiotic," (mockingly,) "*the hanged man*. Way too simple."

links.title: You: ""I'm not *feeling* it.""
links.text: "I'm not *feeling* it."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Are you sure? I think it's pretty..."
links.text: "Are you sure? I think it's pretty serviceable..."

links.title: You: ""Okay, let's keep it.""
links.text: "Okay, let's keep it."

links.title: You: ""Yeah, not feeling it.""
links.text: "Yeah, not feeling it."

links.title: You: ""Let me guess -- the HANGED MAN?""
links.text: "Let me guess -- the HANGED MAN?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Oh! That's actually what *I* was t..."
links.text: "Oh! That's actually what *I* was thinking -- THE HANGED MAN." He nods. "I like that. A good, strong name. We have a very good name for the case now."

links.title: You: "(Count the pages.) I have to open a..."
links.text: (Count the pages.) I have to open an official case. Is there room?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "There is -- for precisely *one* mor..."
links.text: There is -- for precisely *one* more. Fifteen pages near the end remain untouched by the damage. The chequered grid forms a structure of passages, breaking the case into sub-tasks to accomplish.

links.title: Logic: "Once all the tasks are accomplished..."
links.text: Once all the tasks are accomplished, the case is complete.

links.title: You: "COMMIT TO PAPER."
links.text: COMMIT TO PAPER.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The tasks you've completed flow out..."
links.text: The tasks you've completed flow out of the pen in a brash freehand similar to the rest of the letters. The wording comes easily, it's almost robotically simple; a language developed for mental rigour and simplicity:

links.title: Damaged Ledger: ""Inspect victim's body.""
links.text: "Inspect victim's body."

links.title: Damaged Ledger: ""Get the body down.""
links.text: "Get the body down."

links.title: Damaged Ledger: ""Interview the cafeteria manager.""
links.text: "Interview the cafeteria manager."

links.title: Conceptualization: "It's not exactly poetry -- but poet..."
links.text: It's not exactly poetry -- but poetry would be out of place.

links.title: You: "Cross out the ones you've already f..."
links.text: Cross out the ones you've already finished.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "A satisfying slash sounds across th..."
links.text: A satisfying slash sounds across the paper. *You're done* it seems to say. And *you!* -- and *you!*

links.title: Half Light: "AND A FUCK YOU TO YOU *TOO*! That l..."
links.text: AND A FUCK YOU TO YOU *TOO*! That last one cuts a slash right through the paper.

links.title: Interfacing: "You're a swashbuckler with that pen..."
links.text: You're a swashbuckler with that pen, Harry. And it feels good. Feels like *completion*.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Things to be done and things alread..."
links.text: Things to be done and things already done -- the composition of reality. This is an extremely useful tool for a detective of the Citizens Militia.

links.title: You: ""Lieutenant, have you by any chance..."
links.text: "Lieutenant, have you by any chance *named* our case?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""No -- actually. Any ideas?""
links.text: "No -- actually. Any ideas?"

links.title: Esprit de Corps: "This would also be a good time to f..."
links.text: This would also be a good time to finally *name* the case -- if only Lieutenant Kitsuragi were here so you could coordinate. No use naming it without him... maybe at a later time you can come back to this?

links.title: Conceptualization: "Sadly, the ledger only comes with a..."
links.text: Sadly, the ledger only comes with an old worn-down led pencil. It's unfitting of this monumental event.

links.title: Interfacing: "The ledger only comes with an old w..."
links.text: The ledger only comes with an old worn-down led pencil. It will *do*, barely... but...

links.title: You: ""Kim, do you have a pen?""
links.text: "Kim, do you have a pen?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant looks at his blue no..."
links.text: The lieutenant looks at his blue notebook. *Two* fat, shiny pens hang from the binder, like large calibre bullets on an ammo belt.

links.title: Suggestion: "It's downright *incriminating*. He..."
links.text: It's downright *incriminating*. He has little choice but to give you one, although he really does not want to.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "He is not really saying anything. J..."
links.text: He is not really saying anything. Just standing there -- looking at them.

links.title: You: ""You know you have to give one to m..."
links.text: "You know you have to give one to me, right? That *is* how human society works, I believe."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "Wordless, he pulls one from the loo..."
links.text: Wordless, he pulls one from the loop and hands it to you. The pen is cold, blue, and ready to write.

links.title: You: "With this beauty -- *COMMIT TO PAPE..."
links.text: With this beauty -- *COMMIT TO PAPER*.

links.title: You: ""Can I have one?""
links.text: "Can I have one?"

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Know that I give this to you..." H..."
links.text: "Know that I give this to you..." He pulls one from the loop. "...with *resentment*."

links.title: You: ""Fine, I'll just use this crappy pe..."
links.text: "Fine, I'll just use this crappy pencil..."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "Absolutely motionless at first, the..."
links.text: Absolutely motionless at first, then animated slowly, imperceptibly even, the lieutenant begins to browse his notes again. Leaving you to the case files.

links.title: Empathy: "The threat has passed. He is thankf..."
links.text: The threat has passed. He is thankful it has passed, and that he's gotten to keep both pens.

links.title: You: "No matter. I'll just use the pencil..."
links.text: No matter. I'll just use the pencil...

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "You start scratching the tasks you'..."
links.text: You start scratching the tasks you've completed onto the paper with a brash freehand uncannily similar to the rest of the letters. The wording comes easily, it's almost robotically simple; a language developed for mental rigour and simplicity:

links.title: You: "(Back to the case files.)"
links.text: (Back to the case files.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Like a fan of gills the chequered p..."
links.text: Like a fan of gills the chequered papers dry in your hand. The handwriting is extremely dense, if mostly illegible.

links.title: You: "I'm done inspecting these. (Close t..."
links.text: I'm done inspecting these. (Close the case files.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "You don't exactly *close* them, so..."
links.text: You don't exactly *close* them, so much as *distance* yourself from the smelly papers. They're a little further from your nose now.

links.title: You: "Browse the *white* papers."
links.text: Browse the *white* papers.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "They're not *exactly* white. They'r..."
links.text: They're not *exactly* white. They're yellowed in patches by sunlight and alcohol, and covered in dense blue handwriting. Ink escapes into watercolour patterns, reaching its tendrils across entire pages. The paper itself is chequered with faint red lines forming short paragraphs.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Once in a while there's a red stamp..."
links.text: Once in a while there's a red stamp that exclaims: CASE FILES; COMMIT TO PAPER. The *CASE FILES* themselves are plenty. You count more than a hundred sodden, crumpled up, earmarked pages falling apart in your hands. They appear to be sufficiently organized and extremely dense, if mostly illegible.

links.title: You: "What is in there -- what are they a..."
links.text: What is in there -- what are they about?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Work. Strife. Poverty. The Jamrock..."
links.text: Work. Strife. Poverty. The Jamrock Quarter. These are handwritten logs of investigations dating back to January '51, this year. The exact number is hard to estimate due to missing pages -- and an *odd* naming convention -- but there are at least twenty, maybe thirty cases. Undertaken, not completed, mind you.

links.title: Logic: "It's the middle of March -- you hav..."
links.text: It's the middle of March -- you have attempted two cases a week on average.

links.title: Reaction Speed: "What do you mean? Is that *all*?"
links.text: What do you mean? Is that *all*?

links.title: You: "Read a case file."
links.text: Read a case file.

links.title: Logic: "It takes about half an hour to piec..."
links.text: It takes about half an hour to piece one together, using the system you've devised. Which one do you want?

links.title: You: "THE NEXT WORLD MURAL"
links.text: THE NEXT WORLD MURAL

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "This one is relatively easy to reco..."
links.text: This one is relatively easy to reconstruct. Overnight on 12/02. a graffito -- nay, a mural! -- appears on an eight story tenement overlooking Central Jamrock. The building is a sparsely inhabited ghost tower, part of a failed real estate development called Grand Couron.

links.title: Rhetoric: "(Cause of failure: rent too high.)"
links.text: (Cause of failure: rent too high.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The mural is enormous. Two silhouet..."
links.text: The mural is enormous. Two silhouettes -- a man and a woman -- are kissing. The text cut into their forms reads:

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "TRUE LOVE IS POSSIBLE ONLY IN THE..."
links.text:
TRUE LOVE IS POSSIBLE
ONLY IN THE NEXT WORLD -- FOR NEW PEOPLE
IT IS TOO LATE FOR US

WREAK HAVOC ON THE MIDDLE CLASS

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "People call it *that thing* and *th..."
links.text: People call it *that thing* and *that fucking thing*. It‚Äôs visible for miles. In two days the station's complaints desk gets clogged with requests to remove *The Bummer*. You and your partner are assigned to the case.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The graffito crew is easy to track..."
links.text: The graffito crew is easy to track down. Only the Belles Lettres have the *literage* of industrial paint to cover the surface. (One of the graffito artists is rumoured to be *rich*.) They take responsibility for the execution, but not the design. The ideologue of the *Next World Mural* -- as the crew calls it -- remains an unknown.

links.title: You: "Wait, do I ever find out who came u..."
links.text: Wait, do I ever find out who came up with it?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The case files do not show you find..."
links.text: The case files do not show you finding the author of the design.

links.title: You: "Read on."
links.text: Read on.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The crew agrees to clean up after t..."
links.text: The crew agrees to clean up after themselves. However, your partner -- JV -- is against the removal, citing public support for conservation. This leads to a debate in Precinct 41, which then spreads to the streets of Jamrock. Ending in a rare plebiscite -- organized by you and the rest of Row III.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The nine thousand people subjected..."
links.text: The nine thousand people subjected to the mural‚Äôs message -- all of Lakeside (Central Jamrock) and Villalobos, plus half of the Eminent Domain -- participate in the vote. Although the case begins with what appears to be a lot of rumbling on the streets as to how juvenile and stupid the mural is, given a choice between two options...

links.title: You: "A) REMOVE THE MURAL, IT IS WRONG"
links.text: A) REMOVE THE MURAL, IT IS WRONG

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "A staggering seventy-eight percent..."
links.text: A staggering seventy-eight percent of voters choose to keep it. Turns out the opposition were a loud minority. And that love truly is possible in the next world -- for new people. And it is too late for us.

links.title: You: "All that remains is to wreak havoc..."
links.text: All that remains is to wreak havoc on the middle class.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "In any case, it appears to have bee..."
links.text: In any case, it appears to have been a rare case of civil activity in the Quarter. And agreement as well. What do you want to tackle next?

links.title: You: "The middle class are not to be blam..."
links.text: The middle class are not to be blamed. It's *human nature*.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Did anyone ask what you believe in,..."
links.text: Did anyone ask what you believe in, man with the smelly toilet ledger? What do you want to tackle next? Or are we done?

links.title: You: "I like it, but can't we wreak havoc..."
links.text: I like it, but can't we wreak havoc on *other nations* instead?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Did someone ask what you believe in..."
links.text: Did someone ask what you believe in, man with the smelly toilet ledger? What do you want to tackle next? Or are we done?

links.title: You: "I must have voted (and possibly eve..."
links.text: I must have voted (and possibly even lobbied) to remove the thing because I don't believe in that rubbish one bit.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "No one cares what you believe in, m..."
links.text: No one cares what you believe in, man with the smelly toilet ledger. What do you want to tackle next? Or are we done?

links.title: You: "B) KEEP THE MURAL, IT IS RIGHT"
links.text: B) KEEP THE MURAL, IT IS RIGHT

links.title: You: "THE UNSOLVABLE CASE"
links.text: THE UNSOLVABLE CASE

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "AKA LESLIE & BURKE, AKA THE PUBLIC..."
links.text: AKA LESLIE & BURKE, AKA THE PUBLIC INDECENCY DRUNK & THE PROPERTY DAMAGE DRUNK is a *cursed* case. It has been passed from unsuspecting officer to unsuspecting officer for ten years. On January 29, THE UNSOLVABLE CASE made its way to you. Why you accepted it is unclear. Every officer and indeed most civilians in Jamrock know it's UNSOLVABLE.

links.title: Electrochemistry: "You were so drunk you didn't rememb..."
links.text: You were so drunk you didn't remember what it was when you signed on. That, or you were high.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Leslie will always take his pants o..."
links.text: Leslie will always take his pants off when he's drunk. Burke will always trash everything. It's just what they do. It is their nature -- you cannot change the nature of a man. And you can't lock them away, because public indecency and small-scale property damage are not punishable by incarceration.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The only way for Leslie to stop dis..."
links.text: The only way for Leslie to stop displaying his genitals, and for Burke to stop attacking things, would be for them to *stop drinking alcohol*. Which in their forties, or fifties -- it's hard to tell because of their distorted features -- is a medical improbability.

links.title: You: "Couldn't we just keep them off the..."
links.text: Couldn't we just keep them off the streets?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "You would think that, but you're wr..."
links.text: You would think that, but you're wrong. Where's the fun in exposing your genitals, or breaking stuff in your own home? No, Leslie and Burke are on the corner of Main Street and Perdition, because that's where the *action* is.

links.title: Logic: "Can you keep *yourself* off the str..."
links.text: Can you keep *yourself* off the streets?

links.title: You: "Proceed."
links.text: Proceed.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Threatening, fines, dragging them t..."
links.text: Threatening, fines, dragging them to the station, locking them up in the hell holes they live in, locking them up in the station, hypnotherapy -- even trying to get a local gang of *zemlyakis* to take them out (the zemlyakis gave them ethanol so Burke and Leslie would expose and rampage even harder) -- you tried it all. And still the complaints wouldn't stop. As they hadn't stopped for *ten years*.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "It's plain to see from the files th..."
links.text: It's plain to see from the files that you, Satellite-Officer JV, and special consultant TH had more important cases to attend to. You uncover cross-reference to several ongoing investigations, each brought to a standstill every time you drive down Main Street. Because there they are! On the corner of Perdition, and what is Leslie doing?

links.title: You: "Property damage."
links.text: Property damage.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "No, that's Burke. Leslie's *schtick..."
links.text: No, that's Burke. Leslie's *schtick* is flashing his genitals, remember? How will you ever solve THE UNSOLVABLE CASE if you can't even get that straight? Well, turns out it's pretty simple. The case becomes *considerably* less comic one day, when Burke takes a swing at your ledger.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "He must have it confused with the *..."
links.text: He must have it confused with the *property* he likes to damage. But the joke's on him -- you're also drunk. Drunk out of your mind on Potent Pilsner. You slam the hardened plastic board in his face; then proceed to beat him unconscious with it.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "In the process the ledger sustains..."
links.text: In the process the ledger sustains damage. The compartment within -- reserved for permeable documents -- is jammed shut. You stop your assault on the now unconscious Burke to open it, but are unable to do so. *The officer began to cry*, reports Leslie, who at this point is tending to Burke.

links.title: Half Light: "Kill them. They broke it."
links.text: Kill them. They broke it.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "*He came at us* -- *And at us* -- *..."
links.text: *He came at us* -- *And at us* -- *I think he was trying to kill Burke-o*. While trying to kill Burke-o, you slowly come around. The permeables' compartment is open. You've smashed it open on poor Burke'o's kneecaps. The good news is, Burke can't walk anymore.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Can't get out of his apartment. An..."
links.text: Can't get out of his apartment. An invalid. With Burke to tend to, Leslie cuts back on the indecent exposure. Maybe he flashes his genitals to Burke, who knows, but both drunks are off the street. The complaints stop, the unsolvable case is solved.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Which is also why the officer respo..."
links.text: Which is also why the officer responsible (narrowly) escapes a disciplinary hearing. The end.

links.title: Logic: "Does that sound like a Rapha√´l Some..."
links.text: Does that sound like a Rapha√´l Something Costeau to you, sir?

links.title: You: "One last time -- YES."
links.text: One last time -- YES.

links.title: Logic: "Fine, then -- then you've earned it"
links.text: Fine, then -- then you've earned it

links.title: You: "Okay, you're right, it doesn't."
links.text: Okay, you're right, it doesn't.

links.title: Logic: "Dammit, take it anyway. Since you s..."
links.text: Dammit, take it anyway. Since you so obviously *want* to be a detective Costeau.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Which is also why the officer respo..."
links.text: Which is also why the officer responsible (narrowly) escapes a disciplinary hearing. The end. Do you want to read another one?

links.title: You: "Public indecency."
links.text: Public indecency.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Good, you're learning. If the files..."
links.text: Good, you're learning. If the files are to be trusted -- that's all there is to it. That and Burke breaking things. And the fact that they're both drunk. But then again, so are you. The case becomes *considerably* less comic one day, when Burke takes a swing at your ledger.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "He must have it confused with the *..."
links.text: He must have it confused with the *property* he likes to damage. But the joke's on him -- you're drunk out of your mind on Potent Pilsner. You slam the hardened plastic board in his face. Then you proceed to beat him unconscious with it.

links.title: You: "THE SQUARE BULLET HOLE MURDERS"
links.text: THE SQUARE BULLET HOLE MURDERS

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "It would be *very* interesting to r..."
links.text: It would be *very* interesting to read about these, wouldn't it? I mean -- there seems to be a *square*-shaped entry wound in the victim's forehead. She's been sitting there for weeks. On her rocking chair. With a square hole in her skull, staring at the wall, her mouth agape.

links.title: You: "But?"
links.text: But?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "That's all you got. From the half h..."
links.text: That's all you got. From the half hour you've spent piecing it together, all you know is: the entry wound was square-shaped. You never found the bullet. And then -- another body showed up. Also with a square hole in his forehead.

links.title: Electrochemistry: "Toxicology showed the entry wound w..."
links.text: Toxicology showed the entry wound was laced with an incredibly potent psychoactive substance called HUV4-Nil. No street name.

links.title: You: "A sequence killer?"
links.text: A sequence killer?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Who knows? Those pages are missing...."
links.text: Who knows? Those pages are missing. What next?

links.title: Inland Empire: "Don't worry. One day."
links.text: Don't worry. One day.

links.title: Conceptualization: "One day you may still catch the man..."
links.text: One day you may still catch the man with the square gun.

links.title: You: "THE COUCH IN AN UNEXPECTED LOCATION"
links.text: THE COUCH IN AN UNEXPECTED LOCATION

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Some assholes brought their couch o..."
links.text: Some assholes brought their couch outside and *hung out* on it. In the middle of the street, on the roof, on the hillside by the motorway. You know -- at an *unexpected location*. They were young and they thought they looked cool on it.

links.title: You: "They actually looked like assholes."
links.text: They actually looked like assholes.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Insufferable dicks. Young people ar..."
links.text: Insufferable dicks. Young people are the worst.  So anyway -- you got a complaint about the damn sofa. Or couch. Or whatever it was.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "They were leaving it out in all the..."
links.text: They were leaving it out in all these *unexpected and whimsical locations* they took it to. Where they also took photos of themselves -- on it. And smoked cigarettes. And drank coffee, because they felt it's *intellectual*.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Cigarette butts, coffee cups, stupi..."
links.text: Cigarette butts, coffee cups, stupid couch. You had to clean it all up. And you *did* -- so congratulations to you. Case solved.

links.title: You: "Did I ever catch those guys?"
links.text: Did I ever catch those guys?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "No. You didn't have time for that,..."
links.text: No. You didn't have time for that, these notes show that you have what is called *a real god damn job*. You don't have time to be chasing down the couch-assholes. You have a real job to do. What next?

links.title: You: "They looked really cool. Like model..."
links.text: They looked really cool. Like models.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yes. As you've said here: total ass..."
links.text: Yes. As you've said here: total assholes. Young people are the worst.  So anyway -- you got a complaint about the damn sofa. Or couch. Or whatever it was.

links.title: You: "They looked really cool. Like a roc..."
links.text: They looked really cool. Like a rock band.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yes. As you've said here: insuffera..."
links.text: Yes. As you've said here: insufferable rock-and-roll assholes. Young people are the worst. So anyway -- you got a complaint about the damn sofa. Or couch. Or whatever it was.

links.title: You: "MURDER AT THE HOOKAH PARLOUR"
links.text: MURDER AT THE HOOKAH PARLOUR

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "MURDER -- tam-tam-tam! -- AT THE HO..."
links.text: MURDER -- tam-tam-tam! -- AT THE HOOKAH PARLOUR! was a case originally assigned to an officer called Joseph Mills, who is now dead. Of circumstances completely unconnected to MURDER AT THE HOOKAH PARLOUR.

links.title: You: "Wait -- how?"
links.text: Wait -- how?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Beaten to death by a throng of Vill..."
links.text: Beaten to death by a throng of Villalobos gang-members when him and his partner J. M. (only initials mentioned) answered a call one night. It's a sad story and it isn't really represented in *your* case files. Stop stalling and get to the MURDER AT THE HOOKAH PARLOUR.

links.title: You: "Right. On with the murder."
links.text: Right. On with the murder.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Joseph Mills was on this case that..."
links.text: Joseph Mills was on this case that he just couldn't solve. Was doing it solo. Said it was a real nutcracker. A real brain-twister. Was on it for, like, a month -- the captain got impatient. Shit or get off the pot, Mills.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Mills didn't get off the pot -- not..."
links.text: Mills didn't get off the pot -- not yet. He kept at it for a couple of weeks more, racking his brains, running with every theory, as outlandish as they seemed -- still couldn't solve the MURDER AT THE HOOKAH PARLOUR. Tough case, he said. Toughest he's ever had.

links.title: You: "Wait -- was Joseph Mills a good cop..."
links.text: Wait -- was Joseph Mills a good cop?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "No, he was awful. Awful sense of hu..."
links.text: No, he was awful. Awful sense of humour too. The worst jokes you've ever heard. Really rapey. Still -- he'd been on it for *months* now. Said it was THE FINAL CASE. Said it was UNCRACKABLE. That the murderer vanished into THIN AIR. That goddamn hookah parlour was all he talked about.

links.title: You: "Go on."
links.text: Go on.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Okay, so the case is handed to you..."
links.text: Okay, so the case is handed to you because Mills isn't getting anywhere. And you look into it. Here's the set-up: A young man is found dead in a hookah parlour. You know, those places where you go and smoke bubblegum-flavoured vapour all day.

links.title: You: "Can you get high off it?"
links.text: Can you get high off it?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "No, it's soot and water vapour. It..."
links.text: No, it's soot and water vapour. It doesn't do anything.

links.title: You: "Really cool."
links.text: Really cool.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yeah, really lame. So anyway -- you..."
links.text: Yeah, really lame. So anyway -- young man, in his twenties, found with his skull busted open. Right on the floor of the hookah parlour. In the middle of the day. No one else is in there. Only client that day. In perfect health too, some kind of movie producer.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "No one enters -- no one exits. He's..."
links.text: No one enters -- no one exits. He's just sucking on his watermelon hookah all morning, all noon, like he usually does. (He's a regular). No calls, nothing. Just sucking on the hookah, until 15.45. Then bam -- he's dead on floor with his skull busted open, blood everywhere. What happened? How can it be?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Mills has no idea. Invisible assass..."
links.text: Mills has no idea. Invisible assassin. Movie deal gone sour. Girl at the counter did it. Nothing fits. Eerie. Man just dropped dead. So you go to the parlour. You see cushions around the table. Table's low, heavy, really sharp edge...

links.title: You: "He sucked hookah, stood up, passed..."
links.text: He sucked hookah, stood up, passed out, hit his head on the table and died?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "See! You can't even *read* the thin..."
links.text: See! You can't even *read* the thing without solving it. Yeah. It was that. Turns out hookah *does* do something -- it turns off your brain's oxygen supply. And you don't notice it until you get up to go to the bathroom.

links.title: You: "He must have sucked a lot of it."
links.text: He must have sucked a lot of it.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yeah, he liked his hookah. Steven w..."
links.text: Yeah, he liked his hookah. Steven was his name.

links.title: You: "And what was he *doing* there -- fo..."
links.text: And what was he *doing* there -- for six hours?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Smoking hookah. Didn't you hear? I..."
links.text: Smoking hookah. Didn't you hear? I don't know. Trying to come up with a movie script maybe. Anyway, that was MURDER AT THE HOOKAH PARLOUR, Joseph Mills wasn't a good detective, and about 30 minutes has passed piecing it together. Next?

links.title: You: "Really stupid."
links.text: Really stupid.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yeah. So anyway -- young man, in hi..."
links.text: Yeah. So anyway -- young man, in his twenties, found with his skull busted open. Right on the floor of the hookah parlour. In the middle of the day. No one else is in there. Only client that day. In perfect health too, some kind of movie producer.

links.title: You: "COLLAPSING TENEMENT"
links.text: COLLAPSING TENEMENT

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "This one's bad. Not that far from P..."
links.text: This one's bad. Not that far from Precinct 41 -- in Central Jamrock -- there is an eight story apartment building with two hundred residents inside. It's the dead of winter, January. Snowing. Someone's beating their wife. It's half past midnight.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "You get a complaint -- no one's the..."
links.text: You get a complaint -- no one's there to take it. So you do call duty. The beating is taking place on the eighth floor. You take the elevator up. The building's creaking around you. Cold as hell. It's a run down old place. Concrete panels, rats everywhere.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "And it's not pretty in the apartmen..."
links.text: And it's not pretty in the apartment either. By the time you arrive the husband's left. His wife has got her lip busted, face swollen. Eyes shut. Can't leave him, they're a *financial unit*. Enjoying this beautiful life in this beautiful tenement.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "So anyway -- you take a leak before..."
links.text: So anyway -- you take a leak before you leave.

links.title: You: "In the apartment I got the call to?"
links.text: In the apartment I got the call to?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yes, cops do that. *While* you're t..."
links.text: Yes, cops do that. *While* you're taking a piss, you see a big crack in the wall. In the outer wall of the building. You can *feel* the cold air blow in. You take the elevator down, look up -- a big crack runs on the outer wall of the whole building.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Right from the foundation -- up to..."
links.text: Right from the foundation -- up to the eighth floor.

links.title: Visual Calculus: "Oh god..."
links.text: Oh god...

links.title: Inland Empire: "No, no, no, no..."
links.text: No, no, no, no...

links.title: Half Light: "Fucking hell."
links.text: Fucking hell.

links.title: You: "The tilt is beyond the point of max..."
links.text: The tilt is beyond the point of maximum deviation from the gravity bearing perpendicular. This means that the building is falling -- and will fall no matter what.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "That's right. They trained you for..."
links.text: That's right. They trained you for this in cop school. Everyone has to pick a civil specialization so they can keep the city running: fire safety, first aid training, and so on. You took *building safety regulation*. And it tells you that this one -- is coming down.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Maybe not tonight. Maybe not even t..."
links.text: Maybe not tonight. Maybe not even tomorrow. Maybe not the day after, but it's coming down. In a matter of days. It is physically impossible for it not to. And the two hundred people in there? They are all going down with it. The woman with the busted lip, the husband who beats her, their kids in the other room...

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The drunk in the hallway. The girl..."
links.text: The drunk in the hallway. The girl in the elevator when you were going up. The youths on the stairs, laughing, smoking. The couple next to the apartment -- who made the call. They're all going to die.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "But, you see, it's *freezing* outsi..."
links.text: But, you see, it's *freezing* outside. And there is no municipal government in Revachol. Nowhere to put these people. Two hundred people can't go to their *aunt's for a couple of days*. And above all -- there is no one to *tell* the building is coming down. No authority but you.

links.title: You: "I'm gonna have to knock on every do..."
links.text: I'm gonna have to knock on every door and explain them how load bearing perpendiculars work?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Bad, bad thoughts go through your h..."
links.text: Bad, bad thoughts go through your head. So what you do is -- you call your partner. JV (only initials available) is up. He comes immediately. He didn't take building safety, but he believes you. He brings five more officers. Together you knock on *every door* and explain the situation.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The load bearing perpendicular. The..."
links.text: The load bearing perpendicular. The maximum deviation. All of it... Some people believe you. Most don't. Some you have to *forcibly* remove. Some even pull guns on you. It takes 20 hours to evacuate the whole building. 200 people stand outside in the cold. Children cry.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Your captain puts them in a half-bu..."
links.text: Your captain puts them in a half-burned building 10 km South. It's got black mould and no roof, but hey -- it's better than death.

links.title: You: "And then what?"
links.text: And then what?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "And then the building doesn't come..."
links.text: And then the building doesn't come down. And it still hasn't. That was 52 days ago. BUT THAT IS NOT THE POINT. The point is -- it *will* come down.

links.title: You: "Am I *absolutely* sure?"
links.text: Am I *absolutely* sure?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "100000000000%"
You: "And when it does, everyone in there..."
links.text: And when it does, everyone in there will die.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "At the end of the day -- no one kno..."
links.text: At the end of the day -- no one knows. The math says it *must* collapse. And the optics show that it doesn't. It's as if some kind of *evil spirit* is holding the tenement together, like the jaws of a trap. Luring the people back in. One by one. Already they're going... At least 40 of them are living there now.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "As we speak. And you can't *keep* t..."
links.text: As we speak. And you can't *keep* them from going back, because they all hate you. They despise you. They think you threw them out of their homes. Every day they despise you more -- and every day, more of them go back.

links.title: You: "And every day is a day closer to th..."
links.text: And every day is a day closer to the day the building will fall.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Exactly. These notes have been very..."
links.text: Exactly. These notes have been very clear. Seems you have been thorough with documenting this one. So -- which one of these do you want to read *next*? (Because there is nothing you can do about THE COLLAPSING TENEMENT).

links.title: You: "If it hasn't, it won't. I was wrong..."
links.text: If it hasn't, it won't. I was wrong.

links.title: You: "Oh god, I don't know..."
links.text: Oh god, I don't know...

links.title: You: "I'm gonna have to go home and do no..."
links.text: I'm gonna have to go home and do nothing, not think about this ever again.

links.title: You: "I'm gonna have to find my captain s..."
links.text: I'm gonna have to find my captain somewhere, first thing tomorrow. Maybe even *tonight*.

links.title: You: "I can revisit this. (Put the case f..."
links.text: I can revisit this. (Put the case files away.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Not much has changed in the meanwhi..."
links.text: Not much has changed in the meanwhile -- a bunch of sodden papers still sags from the clipboard.

links.title: You: "Can I read the case files now?"
links.text: Can I read the case files now?

links.title: Logic: "Yes! You can piece them together us..."
links.text: Yes! You can piece them together using the alphanumeric code on the margin. It always begins with HDB41, then date of initialization and time of arrival on the scene. Followed by the title. For example: HDB41120117:00 (THE NEXT WORLD MURAL).

links.title: You: "Wait... HDB41? Weren't those: 'Offi..."
links.text: Wait... HDB41? Weren't those: 'Officer, precinct'?

links.title: Logic: "Why yes. Your precinct number is 41..."
links.text: Why yes. Your precinct number is 41.

links.title: You: "And HDB..."
links.text: And HDB...

links.title: Logic: "Every last alphanumeric in the file..."
links.text: Every last alphanumeric in the files begins with it -- and these are *your* case files. It's safe to say H.D.B. are your initials.

links.title: Logic:"Harrier Du Bois -- H.D.B."
links.text: Harrier Du Bois -- H.D.B.

links.title: You: "Fine, then. I give up on Rapha√´l..."
links.text: Fine, then. I give up on Rapha√´l...

links.title: Logic:"Harry Du Bois -- H.D.B."
links.text: Harry Du Bois -- H.D.B.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Still feels like there's *something..."
links.text: Still feels like there's *something* missing from that...

links.title: You: "Horus Debby Berenger?"
links.text: Horus Debby Berenger?

links.title: Logic: "That... is improbable."
links.text: That... is improbable.

links.title: You: "Hram Darjan Binzakin?"
links.text: Hram Darjan Binzakin?

links.title: Logic: "Yeah... no."
links.text: Yeah... no.

links.title: You: "Those aren't my initials, I'm not *..."
links.text: Those aren't my initials, I'm not *feeling* them.

links.title: Logic: "*Feeling* isn't really the jurisdic..."
links.text: *Feeling* isn't really the jurisdiction we're in right now.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Probably for the best. Because HDB..."
links.text: Probably for the best. Because HDB feels like *bad news* from yesteryear. Like shit, honcho.

links.title: You: "Wow. I don't know what to say to th..."
links.text: Wow. I don't know what to say to that.

links.title: Logic: "I got nothing here either. Logic re..."
links.text: I got nothing here either. Logic really isn't the best faculty to have this conversation with, But it's the one you got, so sorry.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Yeah, we're staying out of this bus..."
links.text: Yeah, we're staying out of this business for now. HDB is *bad news* from yesteryear. It's shit, honcho.

links.title: You: "I think what you *meant* to say was..."
links.text: I think what you *meant* to say was RAC -- *Rapha√´l Ambrosius Costeau*.

links.title: Logic: "No, the alphanumeric begins with HD..."
links.text: No, the alphanumeric begins with HDB.

links.title: Drama: "Can't you see the *sire* is tired o..."
links.text: Can't you see the *sire* is tired of these... fabrications. *RAC* is clearly what it says on the case files. These are official documents. There is no arguing with *official* documents.

links.title: You: "Good. How long does it take to read..."
links.text: Good. How long does it take to read one of these *Rapha√´l-stamped* cases? (Persist.)

links.title: Logic: "Fine. It takes about half an hour f..."
links.text: Fine. It takes about half an hour for you to piece one together, Mr... Rapha√´l. Which one do you want?

links.title: You: "Actually, I'm ready to admit I'm no..."
links.text: Actually, I'm ready to admit I'm not Rapha√´l and go on with my life.

links.title: Logic: "That's comforting to hear. Now, det..."
links.text: That's comforting to hear. Now, detective. It takes half an hour to piece one of these together -- if you still want to. Here are your options.

links.title: You: "Wait! What is HDB41?"
links.text: Wait! What is HDB41?

links.title: Logic: "Forty one is your precinct."
links.text: Forty one is your precinct.

links.title: You: "But what is HDB?"
links.text: But what is HDB?

links.title: Logic: "It's safe to say those are the init..."
links.text: It's safe to say those are the initials of the officer responsible for the case -- *your* initials.

links.title: You: "How long does it take to read a cas..."
links.text: How long does it take to read a case?

links.title: Logic: "It takes about half an hour to piec..."
links.text: It takes about half an hour to piece one together, using the system you've devised. Where do you want to start?

links.title: Logic: "It's possible: yes. Easy: no. You n..."
links.text: It's possible: yes. Easy: no. You need to come up with a small archaeological system to re-order the remains of your past works. At the moment all they do is fall apart in your hands. Some dates and the numeric titular system is all you have.

links.title: You: "Browse the *yellow* papers."
links.text: Browse the *yellow* papers.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Thin see-through copier paper -- mo..."
links.text: Thin see-through copier paper -- mostly neon yellow, some bright red -- all covered in boxes like marching armies. These are your official forms, easy enough to make sense of...

links.title: You: "MISCONDUCT FINE."
links.text: MISCONDUCT FINE.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "A monetary penalization ranging fro..."
links.text: A monetary penalization ranging from 20 to 250 re√°l. Severe cases allow for 1000 re√°l, but that requires special paperwork. The details of issuing these fines are spread out over the rest of the fields.

links.title: Rhetoric: "But they appear... pleasantly vague..."
links.text: But they appear... pleasantly vague.

links.title: Suggestion: "A tool for manipulation. Give the l..."
links.text: A tool for manipulation. Give the lowest amount and people will be ingratiated to you.

links.title: You: "STATION CALL."
links.text: STATION CALL.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "These are quite sinister in tone. T..."
links.text: These are quite sinister in tone. They give a date and time for the person to 'appear' at the specified Precinct Police Station. Below the 'call' are the criminal charges you risk by 'not appearing'.

links.title: Perception (Sight): "All in a print so small it could be..."
links.text: All in a print so small it could be considered downright *cute*.

links.title: You: "FIELD AUTOPSY."
links.text: FIELD AUTOPSY.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "A dozen pages of thin copy paper, b..."
links.text: A dozen pages of thin copy paper, bright red in colour. You see the parameters of a deceased human form, waiting to be filled in: age, sex, condition of internal organs...

links.title: Physical Instrument: "Colour of the irises. Predation mar..."
links.text: Colour of the irises. Predation marks. Condition of sexual organs.

links.title: You: ""Kim, look, *field autopsy*.""
links.text: "Kim, look, *field autopsy*."

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: ""Good, yes. We can return to the de..."
links.text: "Good, yes. We can return to the dead body -- by now it smells *exquisite*..." Looks like he would rather concentrate on taking notes for now.

links.title: You: "Let it be."
links.text: Let it be.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The forms feel moist, like the rest..."
links.text: The forms feel moist, like the rest. Wavy to touch.

links.title: You: "Enough of these. (Close forms.)"
links.text: Enough of these. (Close forms.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The rest of the stinking cellulose..."
links.text: The rest of the stinking cellulose is *much* worse for wear. Being sandwiched between the board and the rest of the paperwork must have spared the fragile copier paper.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Yes -- all that remains now is to f..."
links.text: Yes -- all that remains now is to fill those forms and *hand* them to people: fines for wrongdoers, interview requests for bad guys, and field autopsies to *dead* guys.

links.title: Authority: "What delicious power hid within thi..."
links.text: What delicious power hid within this pathetic mess... you feel better.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "In the back you see thin translucen..."
links.text: In the back you see thin translucent copier paper -- some neon yellow, some bright red -- all covered in boxes, like marching armies. These look like official forms, waiting to be filled out...

links.title: Logic: "...then *rip* them from the binder,..."
links.text: ...then *rip* them from the binder, and hand them out. According to type of form.

links.title: You: "What types of forms are there?"
links.text: What types of forms are there?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Three. The topmost are MISCONDUCT F..."
links.text: Three. The topmost are MISCONDUCT FINES, the middle ones  are STATION CALLS, and the bottommost are FIELD AUTOPSY FORMS. Each is easy enough to make sense of.

links.title: Conceptualization: "You don't have to be an intellectua..."
links.text: You don't have to be an intellectual giant to do police-work.

links.title: You: "Look at the clipboard."
links.text: Look at the clipboard.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "It's made of dark blue plastic hard..."
links.text: It's made of dark blue plastic hard enough to beat someone to submission with. The edges are rounded, however. The U4-sized board feels thick and heavy in your hand. Light shimmers on its wet surface. On the back you see the embossed letters: RCM.

links.title: You: "What did you say the colour was?"
links.text: What did you say the colour was?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Blue."
links.text: Blue.

links.title: Inland Empire: "The blue heart. Don't look into it."
links.text: The blue heart. Don't look into it.

links.title: You: "Shake the ledger."
links.text: Shake the ledger.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Something rattles inside, ever so l..."
links.text: Something rattles inside, ever so lightly. Is there... a hidden compartment?

links.title: Perception (Hearing): "And something small inside? Light?..."
links.text: And something small inside? Light?  Made of paper or cardboard? Or dried flowers perhaps?

links.title: Logic: "Permeables. It's not hidden per se,..."
links.text: Permeables. It's not hidden per se, the compartment is made for permeable materials that would get damaged if something happened to it.

links.title: You: "Peek inside."
links.text: Peek inside.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The plastic shimmers like lapis laz..."
links.text: The plastic shimmers like lapis lazuli, but it is not see-through. You cannot see to its centre...

links.title: Perception (Sight): "There's something there. A rectangu..."
links.text: There's something there. A rectangular shape, like one of those *postcards* that Annette told you about...

links.title: Pain Threshold: "There's pain in there, if you want..."
links.text: There's pain in there, if you want some. That much you know.

links.title: Perception (Sight): "There's something there. A rectangu..."
links.text: There's something there. A rectangular shape, like a card. Or a postcard...

links.title: You: "Back to the rest of this mess."
links.text: Back to the rest of this mess.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "U4-sized pages hang from the clip s..."
links.text: U4-sized pages hang from the clip screwed to the top of the board.

links.title: You: "How would I open it? (Conclude.)"
links.text: How would I open it? (Conclude.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "With your hands? U4-sized pages han..."
links.text: With your hands? U4-sized pages hang from the clip screwed to the top of the board.

links.title: You: "Slide the hidden drawer open."
links.text: Slide the hidden drawer open.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Without resistance -- or sound -- t..."
links.text: Without resistance -- or sound -- the two panels move against each other. The compartment is now open.

links.title: You: "Pick up the ticket stubs."
links.text: Pick up the ticket stubs.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Two octopuses are smiling, reaching..."
links.text: Two octopuses are smiling, reaching their tentacles toward each other in the coloured pencil drawings. The tickets permit access to a zoo in Revachol East. The aquarium costs extra -- these let you go there too.

links.title: You: "Pick up the card. (Proceed.)"
links.text: Pick up the card. (Proceed.)

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "You stare at the card, willing your..."
links.text: You stare at the card, willing your hand to move. It refuses. It's too much. Not again.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "No, you don't -- not without offici..."
links.text: No, you don't -- not without official police backup. It's simply impossible to open it. Your hands refuse to move.

links.title: Esprit de Corps: "Somewhere in a station lazareth lie..."
links.text: Somewhere in a station lazareth lieutenant-detective Kitsuragi turns on the side and says: ouch. The wounds are agonizing.

links.title: Inland Empire: "Hmm... it's as if there is an autom..."
links.text: Hmm... it's as if there is an automatic *self-defence* structure in your hand, keeping you from mind-fucking yourself with letters from past lovers.

links.title: Hand/Eye Coordination: "It's me. I'm keeping his hand from..."
links.text: It's me. I'm keeping his hand from moving. We're not doing that anymore. We're not reading those words. People have died. He needs to work, not ache his heart for something that will never return.

links.title: Kim Kitsuragi: "The lieutenant clears his throat. "..."
links.text: The lieutenant clears his throat. "I don't think this is the time to be going through personal affects," he says. "Let's move on."

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Thin wax paper has been glued to a..."
links.text: Thin wax paper has been glued to a piece of cardboard. Sounds like leaves rustling when you pick it up -- you see violet flowers, floral patterns, patches of glue.

links.title: You: "Smell it first."
links.text: Smell it first.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "It smells of chewing gum -- apricot..."
links.text: It smells of chewing gum -- apricot flavoured.

links.title: Perception (Smell): "*Exactly* like the gum wrapper you..."
links.text: *Exactly* like the gum wrapper you found. The same brand of chewing gum...

links.title: Perception (Smell): "A touch of cinnamon, the end of sum..."
links.text: A touch of cinnamon, the end of summer. You think the label says: 'Tutti Frutti'.

links.title: You: "Open it."
links.text: Open it.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Familiar handwriting lines the insi..."
links.text: Familiar handwriting lines the inside of the card -- looped, round letters in a woman's hand.

links.title: Visual Calculus: "A young woman in her twenties. Ther..."
links.text: A young woman in her twenties. There is care, effort, and a *smile*, you think -- although that is not something you can read from someone's handwriting.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: ""Harry," it begins -- you're alread..."
links.text: "Harry," it begins -- you're already reading. "I wanted to write you a letter, so you can read it when you wake up. Maybe it will make you happy."

links.title: Volition: "Throw it away. Please."
links.text: Throw it away. Please.

links.title: You: "But it will make me *happy*..."
links.text: But it will make me *happy*...

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "A merciful wind blows in from the B..."
links.text: A merciful wind blows in from the Bay of Revachol, dusting the ground at your feet and raising newspapers far away. You feel the card slipping into it...

links.title: Shivers: "LET GO."
links.text: LET GO.

links.title: You: "What was that?"
links.text: What was that?

links.title: Shivers: "Frisson covers your entire body. A..."
links.text: Frisson covers your entire body. A feeling of cold. A persistent chill.

links.title: You: "Throw the card in the wind."
links.text: Throw the card in the wind.

links.title: Electrochemistry: "No! Don't throw away the baggie! Th..."
links.text: No! Don't throw away the baggie! There's dust on the drug baggie! It's not good but at least it's *some* kind of way to be together...

links.title: You: "Throw the card in the wind."
links.text: Throw the card in the wind.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Just like that the wind picks it fr..."
links.text: Just like that the wind picks it from your fingers. Cold, they let go, the wax paper rustles, a whisper light and low... Then a sudden gust raises the postcard to the drizzle grey sky above. Away from you...

links.title: Shivers: "A small piece of paper dances above..."
links.text: A small piece of paper dances above Martinaise -- above slow waves crashing the shore; and the war torn houses and the new *batiments nouveau* alike; above you, looking up to the grey sky with your hair greasy and wet..

links.title: Shivers: "And above the distant streets and t..."
links.text: And above the distant streets and the 8/81 -- even above the old fish market and the church. Its material existence is lost. This great city will pocket it for you. For your own sake -- forget about it.

links.title: Electrochemistry: "Synapses can be rerouted. The mind..."
links.text: Synapses can be rerouted. The mind takes a new shape.

links.title: Volition: "Not for yourself -- for the people..."
links.text: Not for yourself -- for the people of Revachol.

links.title: Authority: "For the eighty thousand under your..."
links.text: For the eighty thousand under your jurisdiction.

links.title: Esprit de Corps: "Under Precinct 41, where typewriter..."
links.text: Under Precinct 41, where typewriters fire long into the night, and officers walk the great steps and the bridge. Long after the card has landed in the cold shore waters, its writing dissolved. Material disintegrated.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The wind carries the keepsake away..."
links.text: The wind carries the keepsake away from you -- to the southwest, the pale violet dot disappears.

links.title: You: "What was in there?"
links.text: What was in there?

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "No. You should not have thought bac..."
links.text: No. You should not have thought back at it... Now some of it is on your mind again.

links.title: You: "Look at the ledger again."
links.text: Look at the ledger again.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The Ledger of (Oblivion Induced) Me..."
links.text: The Ledger of (Oblivion Induced) Mental Health is just as shabby as the Damaged Ledger was: a bunch of sodden papers sags from the clipboard in your hand.

links.title: Tutorial Agent: "The Ledger of Oblivion is a special..."
links.text: The Ledger of Oblivion is a special item that can be used both as an INTERACTABLE and a TOOL equipped in your hand for skill bonuses. Find it under the TOOLS tab in your INVENTORY.

links.title: You: "Put the ledger away. [Leave.]"
links.text: Put the ledger away. [Leave.]

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "The Ledger of (Oblivion Induced) Me..."
links.text: The Ledger of (Oblivion Induced) Mental Health is just as shabby as the Damaged Ledger anyway. A bunch of sodden papers on a clipboard. Better not to waste more time with it.

links.title: Tutorial Agent: "The Ledger of Oblivion is a special..."
links.text: The Ledger of Oblivion is a special item that can be used both as an INTERACTABLE and a TOOL equipped in your hand for skill bonuses. Find it under the TOOLS tab in your INVENTORY.

links.title: You: "Hold on to it. Read the card."
links.text: Hold on to it. Read the card.

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Your hands shake holding on to it...."
links.text: Your hands shake holding on to it. "Every morning, when I step out and you're asleep behind me," it says. "I find a little piece of sadness in me. I carry it in my chest down Voyager road..."

links.title: Damaged Ledger: "Outside you hear the wind howl. A s..."
links.text: Outside you hear the wind howl. A sudden gale blows in from Martinaise, flapping street signs and window blinds.

links.title: Shivers: "COME OUTSIDE."
links.text: COME OUTSIDE.

links.title: You: "What?"
